history.content:
1. Why H54? There's no point after doing EE16AB. The math department is usually willing to waive 54 if you take 110 and do well, especially considering that you're a senior. If your advisor says no, just do normal 54. For a student of your standing, H54 is just extra needless work, especially since H54 doesn't introduce anything new, and you'll get the extra rigor in 110 regardless for your math minor.

2. If you loved CS 170, you're in luck. They have 174 in the fall, which is an expansion upon random algorithms (like the hashing stuff introduced in 170). Should be right up your alley. Is any of this useful for a job? Absolutely not. Getting an interview doesn't even require 170 knowledge most of the time, and once you're on the job, you're not gonna do anything more advanced than 61B most likely. I would recommend math 104 and cs 174 in the fall.

3. Are you sure an extra year is worth it? Unless you do theory grad school, in which you absolutely must must must have a PhD, no masters in CS demands a math background stronger than the math 5x series. 

4. Take 162. Just do it. You're in for a bad time as a SWE if you don't have the coding experience. 162's content is dry, but that's not why people take it. People take it because it whips them into shape through a large and challenging project. If you don't like the 162 content, 164 will do much of the same, albeit the class is harder.  There's no job outlook in theory. You might be able to do it for fun at a MS program, but unless you're good enough to get into MSR, you're just gonna end up a SWE like everyone else.

children.subject:
I think you could still stand to take a good mix. Aim to take at least 2 16x course by the time you graduate, simply because it's likely the field the rest of your career is going to be in. I think there are only really two real 17x classes anyways, so you could take them both if you wanted to. 

I think you should give theory a shot if you like it, but be warned that MS programs are rarely funded, so you're gonna have to pay out of pocket. Whether that's worth it or not (to pay to go to even more school) is up to you. But I think it would give you only little advantage in industry.

1) I came into CS kinda late - so haven’t taken EE16A/B. But this is a good point. Since EE16B was only added as a req the year after I came to Cal, I can get by w EE16A and 54 since i have no interest in systems. 

2) Hm, what do you think is more valuable then in filling the CS upper div requirements? 16* courses or 17* courses? Idk how to balance job prep and actually loving my classes. 

3/4) Though I liked CS170, what I really liked about it and CS70 in retrospect was the way it helped me almost recreate the way I think about problems, and it really showed me the beauty of what math can do. I want to explore this as far as I can before I (inevitably) become a SWE like everyone else. I’m fine with that in the long run - I think coding itself is awesome, but just the dev process itself is hell if your team isn’t literally perfect. Its reality. I know. I just feel like I will be miserable if I just leetcode and land a job at Big N and never try for the MS, you know? What do you think?

Student answer here. Because most people don't have that much money. Masters programs are pay-your-way and extra school is extra money. There are realistic financial considerations in studying something that it only useful at the highest echelons, ie theoretical CS.

Obv if OP is loaded to the gills, they can just do what they want, but realistically they must choose a path that leads to a meaningful career without too much financial burden/debt.

I think I largely agree with the point you're making (i.e. financial constraints should matter when picking a plan after undergrad). Good advice!

I disagree with the assumption suggested by your wording: "you're just gonna...end up like everyone else" or "[OP] must choose a path that leads to a meaningful career." Who is everyone else? We are talking about a small sector of students inside just one of many good schools within a tiny slice of the world. You don't have to do anything. Taking a few classes in operating systems or whatever doesn't decree that a meaningful career is in software. The vast majority of jobs fall outside of SWE, and could offer solid financial tracks as well.

ok, thanks for coming to my ted talk.

I find the advice on this thread to be disheartening. The poster clearly has some interest in learning about theory, and disliked the software engineering internship they had over the summer to some degree. Why is the advice to suck it up and "end up a SWE like everyone else"?

I would say: go for a master's if you can afford it, and think you would thoroughly enjoy more school. You are in control of your next few years, and there is no mandate to go into software simply because your major might suggest it. Do what you're interested in, since you have amazing options and are free to pursue anything you'd like.

In other news, I would suggest 174 and maybe EECS 127.

history.content:
Context

•Declared CS senior. 

•I have 3 more CS upper div requirements. 

• I've decided to add a math minor to my degree after taking CS70, CS170. (So, going to take an extra yr)

• I did not do that well in CS70 since at the time I didn't really have an interest in it, but got an A- in CS170. I loved that class, and I THINK I want to focus my schedule more around the theory classes, but don't know how useful they will be.

• After college, I'd like to go for a Masters in CS (doing a SWE internship now and can't see myself doing it right after college).

• I feel like I might be disadvantaged leaving Berkeley without taking classes like CS162. But, after taking 61C last semester with Weaver, I feel like I have FAR less interest in these classes. 

What do you think? I don't want this upcoming semester to be death, so pairing these classes with something like EE126 is not something I'm looking for. I have no interest in CS160. Not sure the difficulty of CS186 and CS161.

Also, I've already gone through 90% of the 104 material this summer together with a graduate student. I still expect it to be nontrivial AF, but just a note. 

EDIT: I got a B in 188 (rip the final lol) so not sure how qualified I’ll be to compete in AI/ML
history.subject: [pls help] Have no idea what class to take with Math 104, Math H54
